ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of new German vocabulary and grammar structures, some of which I knew before but I understand it all a lot better now, especially the different cases.

We learned the basics of the German language and simple grammar rules. The course also focused a bit on German culture, which made it more appealing and entertaining. By the end of the semester, I was able to communicate in German with simple phrases to describe my daily life as well as plans for the future. Overall, it was exactly what one would ideally learn from an A1 course.
I believe I can now not die if I were stranded in Germany. The basics of Germans structure were pretty well hammered  in
I learned basic level German. I understand how to say and read basic sentences and I learned grammar that will help me built my base.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths were that even an L1 class was taught almost totally in German.  We did move through stuff quickly but I think that's more helpful than not when learning a new language.  I think a weakness for me was the amount of time the asynchronous work took.  I don't think it should've taken longer than the 50 minute class, but I was often working on it for a couple hours.
max is such a great professor i cannot recommend him enough!!! the course is very well designed to facilitate quick but effective learning

The strengths of the course were our super helpful instructor (Max), the highly engaging class setting, Friday asynchronous days, and the breadth of topics covered. The only weakness I can potentially think of is that I wish we had spent more time in class explaining German cases instead of pushing that to be a topic for office hours.
I enjoyed this course, there was nothing that felt unnecessary. I enjoyed the final project, instead of a final exam.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  Max is a really fun teacher, it was really helpful also that he has the experience of learning German as a second language.  We learned a lot, but class was always fun with a lot of laughs.

I would absolutely recommend this course to any student who has little to no knowledge of the German language and would like to improve that. My recommendation is enhanced even more if it is an option to have Max Phillips as one's professor. While the workload fluctuates and may become overwhelming by the end of the semester, each class will be super engaging and productive. By the time that the semester ends, I guarantee that you will understand/speak German at an A1 level thanks to the class conversations and projects.
Its intense. If you can handle it with other courses/commitments/life and really wanna learn German and are willing to (likely) put in more work, then yeah. If not, then you will struggle.
Yes, I felt like L1 German was a great class to introduce the language and culture without it being too challenging.
